result.execSummary:
All charges against Nicholas Bradley Teasdale in this case have been dismissed. These charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Nicholas Bradley Teasdale is presumed innocent.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Nicholas Bradley Teasdale

records.addlTxt:
8:42 AM 
Defendant Nicholas Bradley Teasdale appeared by video.  Attorney Alex Gelhar appeared by video for Nicholas Bradley Teasdale.  Attorney Jedidiah J Dodge in court for State of Wisconsin. Victim appears via video.
Case is called.
ADA Dodge states appearances.
State is in compliance with victim rights legislation.
ADA Dodge motions to dismiss this matter.
Court inquires if the victim would like to make a statement.
Victim makes a statement.
Court asks the victim to pull the microphone closer.
Victim continues with statement.
Atty Gelhar states he supports the State's motion to dismiss.

BY THE COURT:
Motion granted.
Matter dismissed without prejudice.

9:49 AM 
Defendant Nicholas Bradley Teasdale in court. Attorney Alex Gelhar in court for Nicholas Bradley Teasdale. Attorney Jedidiah J Dodge in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Court calls the case.
ADA Dodge states appearances.
Matter is set for a final pre-trial.
ADA Dodge moves for a dismissal without prejudice and provides reasoning.
ADA Dodge notes that he has been unable to have sufficient discussion with the victim.
Court asks whether a letter was sent to the victim regarding today's hearing.
ADA Dodge notes that there was not a notice sent.
Atty Gelhar asks that the motion be granted, possibly even with prejudice.
Court responds and asks ADA Dodge if he can take other steps to contact the victim.

BY THE COURT:
Matter set for a motion hearing 09-20-2022 at 8:30 AM.

Court requests that the State send an officer from the Clintonville Police Department out to inform the victim of this matter.

BY THE COURT:
Bond continued.
Motion hearing scheduled for September 20, 2022 at 08:30 am.
Motion hearing on September 20, 2022 at 08:30 am.

10:59 AM Defendant Nicholas Bradley Teasdale not in court.  Defendant is in custody at Waupaca County Jail.   Attorney Jedidiah J Dodge in court for State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Alex Gelhar in court for Nicholas Bradley Teasdale. 

Court calls the case.
ADA Dodge states the appearances.

This was set for a Pretrial but would like to set it for Trial.
Court questions Atty Gelhar and states that he had filed a demand for speedy trial.
Defendant is currently in the Waupaca County Jail.
Court questions ADA Dodge as to how much time he needs.
ADA Dodge would request 2 days.
Atty Gelhar is in agreement with the 2 days.
Court questions if there are any motions of substance that need to be heard prior to trial.
ADA Dodge does not have any motions.
Atty Gelhar states his motions in limine would be more extensive and does not believe that he will have any motions to suppress. 
Court states that there is a jury trial set in the #1 position for the dates as stated on the record.
State has complied with victim rights statutes.
ADA Dodge does not have anything else to put on the record.
Atty Gelhar does not have anything else to put on the record.

BY THE COURT:
Jury Trial - 09/28/22 & 09/29/22 - 2nd position
Final Pretrial - 09/19/22 @ 9:30-10:30 a.m.
